BE11:15am

Theresa May has announced her resignation as Conservative leader, clearing the way for a new UK prime minister to pick up the formidable challenge of delivering Brexit and reuniting a shattered party.

Mrs May said in an emotional statement in Downing Street that she would resign as Tory leader on Friday June 7, triggering a leadership contest that will start the following week which former foreign secretary Boris Johnson is favourite to win.

The prime minister said she would continue in a caretaker role until a new Conservative leader is elected; that process — involving Tory MPs and party activists — is expected to be wrapped up before the end of July.

BE11:23am

Boris’ appeal to Leave voters makes him the bookies’ favourite
Recent polling suggested that Boris Johnson would be the most likely candidate to reverse the trend of
the Conservatives losing votes to the new Brexit Party (Source: Politico-Hanbury). Although the poll
also showed he is unpopular with Remain voters, it suggests it is his appeal to Leave voters that makes
Mr Johnson the front-runner in the betting odds. A key thing to watch for now will be who puts forward
their nominations over the coming days, which should give a better sense of the runners and riders and
who might be Mr Johnson’s biggest challengers.
All told, the UK political landscape has become extremely uncertain. Volatile times lie ahead.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

The final decision on leader is made by Conservative party members, and a majority of members appear to favour a hard Brexit, so the incoming leader is likely to be 'harder' than May in terms of their Brexit views. With the UK set for a no-deal Brexit on October 31, and a parliament opposed to a no-deal outcome, we expect some movement once May's successor is in place. We expect a political process – elections or referendum – to decide the way forward, and see a more binary outcome, with a higher probability of either a hard Brexit (25%) or Remain (45%).

11:24 am
BE11:25am

When she became Prime Minister in 2016 May coined the now infamous but still bewildering catchphrase
'Brexit means Brexit'.The problem was that it was never actually clear what Brexit did mean. Admittedly,
pandering to her Conservative Party’s biases, May did come up with a version of Brexit that largely
addressed the divorce from the EU rather than future relationship, but this failed to gain a majority in a
divided parliament, reflecting similar splits within the electorate.
The Brexit lobby’s aim was for May to preside over the Brexit divorce and then be the scapegoat when
subsequent problems arose as the realities kick in. Instead, the new Prime Minister will inherit this
deadlock when he or she takes office, probably after mid-July. That new Prime Minister may have resorted
to hard-Brexit rhetoric to pander to the euroskeptic Conservative Party membership, albeit with the
central theme being that they alone would be able to renegotiate a new Brexit deal with the EU.
However, the new Prime Minister will soon be alerted to the harsh realities of office, highlighting the
negatives of no-deal Brexit in terms of security, economics and even the existential threat to the UK itself.
More likely than not, the new Prime Minister will use the anti-hard Brexit majority in parliament as an
excuse to not pursue this course. Instead, a further extension to Article 50 looks like the most likely
outcome. We would expect the EU to be amenable to this, especially as the rationale is likely to be a fresh
general election.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Here's SocGen's credit team.

BE11:35am

Casino, as well as Go Sport, is not concerned by these proceedings and Casino’s CEO, Jean-Charles Naouri, will not step down. The French retailer said these procedures do no relate to Casino group or its operations and employees, and do not impact the ongoing execution of its strategic plan. Following the safeguard plan and possible restructuring plan, the change in Casino’s ownership could weigh on the group’ strategy. However, we think that the pressure on Casino’s dividend should decrease to the benefit of Casino’s deleveraging but it would be only for a short-term period depending on the outcome of the procedure. However, at the end of the procedure, a debt haircut is very likely, leading to a change of control. The risk is that Naouri will stay in control and at the end of the safeguard proceeding Casino will resume its dividends towards Rallye. However, this is not our base case.

BE11:36am

(@Fatdaz: yep.)

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Wait, sorry, that was Kepler not SocGen.

BE11:37am

Here's SocGen.

BE11:37am

The good news is that the safeguard proceedings should break the ‘negative circle’ between Casino and Rallye. As a reminder the bulk of Rallye’s credit lines had Casino shares pledged against them – so, the lower the Casino share price, the greater the concerns about Rallye’s refinancing capacity.

FATDAZ @BE thanks
11:37 am
BE11:38am

Having said that, we still have some key questions about the safeguard plan that will have to be validated by the judge. Over the past few years, Casino has distributed a large dividend to Rallye that has enabled Rallye to cover its financial charges but not to reduce its net debt. We think Rallye will have to demonstrate it will be able to repay its debt. The potential triggers could be: 1) a significant improvement in Casino’s FCF generation; 2) and/or asset disposals made by Casino are done under good financial terms, in order to distribute a special dividend to Rallye; 3) and/or potential financial partnerships.

BE11:39am

Kepler -- the equities side this time, and definitely Kepler not SocGen -- saying 10 year payback would be "would be strongly negative for Casino, as it would imply increasing pressure to pay dividends over time, while the company is already struggling to deliver on FCF."

BE11:39am

While the banks are not allowed to sell the Casino shares they have as collateral, we believe they can start selling their debt exposure to Rallye to distressed investors (at a discount), who in return will put pressure on Casino’s share price (to cash in the spread). Moreover, a ten-year debt rescheduling at Rallye will imply that Casino will pay more dividends over ten years (although they could cut dividends first in the short term), which is not in the interest of the minority shareholders. The way out is still a debt haircut at Rallye, and as a result, a change of control leading to the departure of JCN. This is the only way for Casino to come out stronger and to prevent further asset stripping.

nightingale20201 @ FATDAZ....(re your Short Sellers)...yes....Muddy Water has been pretty good over the years....fyi, their first big hit was Sinoforest
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Bruno at Bernstein, meanwhile, is having some fun reading through the detail of French Ch11 law.

BE11:41am

There is a vote amongst the creditors on the plan, but senior bond holders or banks cannot cram down more junior creditors and even shareholders (i.e. Mr. Naouri) have a veto over the plan. Despite seniority and/or collateral, banks and senior creditors have very little leverage.

This leads to the absurd possibility in French bankruptcy law that all the creditors get restructured (i.e. delayed payment, hair cuts, etc.) but that the equity walks away unscathed. This would hopefully be frowned upon by the courts but it is entirely possible.

BE11:42am

Recovery proceedings are more conventional, with regards administrators coming in and so forth.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

The fact that Mr. Naouri was able to convince the courts that Rallye, Fonciere Euris and Finatis are still cash solvent is a major achievement and a win for him. In our view, all those entities are insolvent with negative equity value.

red @BornCynicmore like he will offer you a quid for it
BE11:49am

We upgrade Royal Mail to Buy with a 320p 12-month price target. We believe that the current share price discounts no improvement in the company’s profitability (even after the dividend cut, the stock is yielding 7%), despite clear areas of efficiency potential. We believe that the recent CMD (May 22) signals a clear shift of focus towards the faster growing part of the business, parcels, where the company is pursuing disciplined price increases to improve profitability. Royal Mail aims to become a parcels company that also delivers mail, from being a mail company that also delivers parcels. With the stock trading on just 9x FY20E P/E, we believe that the risk/reward is significantly skewed to the upside (on our estimates, the stock is trading on just 6x FY22E P/E) and upgrade the stock to Buy with a 320p 12-month price target.

Omikin As it's slow, BE, Anything on China's porcine problem and the impact on Genus, etc?
BornCynic @Soundbuy - I am channeling Baldrick.
Soundbuy Royal Mail - locally, delivery vans have seen better days...........
BE11:50am

Royal Mail profitability in recent years has been shrinking, partly due to weaker-than-expected volume performance in mail [partly linked to the weaker macro in the UK]. Its relatively low efficiency in parcels has prevented group profitability from recovering. Crucially, the company has not been able to grow its top line over the last six years in the UK, which has stayed around £7.8bn. We believe this should change, as momentum has accelerated in parcels (volume and revenue growth accelerated in recent quarters to high single digits), while mail volumes in the last year were in particular affected by the one-off introduction of GDPR legislation (which has added c.2% to the mail volume decline from May 2018).

Soundbuy ......watching capex...........
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Here's the efficiency stuff.

BE11:51am

At the same time, productivity growth has picked-up in 2H19 (to +1.9%, from -0.2% in 1H19) and is almost back on track with the historical trend of 2%-3% pa. We believe that there are still at least two areas where Royal Mail can significantly improve its profitability/efficiency, particularly: 1) the company is aiming to increase automated sorting for parcels from 12% today (and zero three years ago) to 80% by 2024; 2) a revision of routes, with a dedicated route for parcels and revised routes for mail deliveries, are likely to meaningfully improve productivity further. The company is targeting to improve productivity by 15%-18% over a five-year period.

BE11:52am

80% automated parcels sorting by 2024! Haha! Yeah, sure, totally.

Even after the dividend cut (rebasing the dividend from 25p to 15p), Royal Mail’s share price implies a 7% dividend yield; the company is due to pay its final dividend (17p, or 8.5% dividend yield) at the end of July. With the stock trading on just 9x FY20E P/E, we believe that the risk/reward is significantly skewed to the upside (on our estimates, the stock is trading on just 6x FY22E P/E) and upgrade the stock to Buy, with a 320p 12-month price target (at our price target, Royal Mail would trade on 12.6x calendar 2020E P/E).

BE12:06pm

Plant-based foods are driving the next phase of portfolio changein Large Cap Food. Our market-sizing exercise, based on estimates for penetration and growth in global dairy, shows that plant-based dairy could be a $70+bn market in 10 years. Barclays’ Global Food report published this week (link) presents a deep dive into the global plant-based meat market and we estimate it could reach ~$140bn over the next ten years, which means together the plant-based foods market could grow from c.$30bn currently to greater than $200bn, i.e.7xin a decade.

GBKrona @BE - possible to add that in the usual place, pls?
BE12:07pm

Consumers are switching from animal protein to plant protein: Younger consumers, especially Gen Z, are replacing meat with plant-based foods in their diet as a result of increased sensitivity to health and environmental issues.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

However,the bigger trend is flexitarians where consumers limit meat consumption (often to weekends only). Kantar estimates that there are 22m flexitarians in the UK and,according to a Waitrose study, a third of Britons have stopped or reduced meat eating.In 2018, the US plant-based segment grew high-single-digits while the overall food industry was flat. Also, given higher price points and lower input costs,e.g. in plant-based dairy, the category is both growth and gross margin accretive. In the UK, average plant based yoghurts are priced at a 20-25% premium to dairy equivalents

GBKrona Veggie Burger misses the point that if I am veggie I don't necessarily want to appear to be eating meat.

Let's be completely clear here, the meat replacement trend is 33% demand led and 66% marketing.

As well as 0% science.

One of our (okay, my) common themes here is that people can taste nearly nothing. Their mouths aren't the subtle, highly calibrated mechanisms they believe.

Upaswellasdown It's like vaping - I used to smoke but stopped. I don't want to walk around with a plastic pipe dangling from my lips

They're just faceholes full of spit and snot. Blind testing shows people can't tell the difference between fish, chicken and jackfruit.

GBKrona @BE - https://thisismold.com/event/experiences/neuroenology-and-the-neuroscience-behind-creating-the-flavor-of-wine#.XOTsC8gzaM8

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Back to Barclays.

BE12:12pm

Danone is the leader in plant-based dairy in EU Food;we remain Overweight:Plant-based is a big part of Danone’s long-term growth algorithm,but one bear argument has been that it would cannibalise dairy sales, but recent launches in markets such as France and Spain show that 80% of Alpro volumes have been incremental. We are waiting with interest the launch of plant-based Activia later this year. The €5bn PB sales target by 2025 might be a stretch, but even if Danone doesn’t quite get there, it shows a growth mentality. Nestlé (OW)and Unilever (UW), on the other hand, are scaling up their plant-based businesses with brand rollouts (Nestle –Incredible Burger) and M&A (Unilever –The Vegetarian Butcher),but we think it is too early to expect a material contribution

BE12:12pm

Meat alternatives is an even bigger addressable market than dairy,but EU Food has relatively lower exposure to this space vs. US Food. Nestlé is expanding its Garden Gourmet range of vegan burgers across Europe and its Incredible Burger is being trialled in McDonald’s in Germany. Unilever’s recent acquisition of The Vegetarian Butcher adds to the 700 products it already sells in Europe with the V-label
